This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.
super explanation
My Solution Is Naive, It Cost O(n^2), Is there Any Solution faster?

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

Is this part correct?

reverse string:  abcxycba

The substring indices are same as reversed string original indices and yet it is not a palindrome?

Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.
super explanation
My Solution Is Naive, It Cost O(n^2), Is there Any Solution faster?

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

Is this part correct? 

example string: abcxycba
reverse string:  abcxycba

The substring indices are same as reversed string original indices and yet it is not a palindrome?

WRONG.\n\nabcxycba reversed is abcyxcba.

Any character in the string by itself is a palindromic substring. So in the case where there is no palindromic substring with length > 1, you can return any character.

Whenever you come accross such contradiction, just google the definition, any. Any string is called is pallindromic if the reverse of the string is equal to the original string. Reverse of \'a\' is \'a\'. Hope you get this.

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.
super explanation
My Solution Is Naive, It Cost O(n^2), Is there Any Solution faster?

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

Is this part correct? 

example string: abcxycba
reverse string:  abcxycba

The substring indices are same as reversed string original indices and yet it is not a palindrome?

WRONG.\n\nabcxycba reversed is abcyxcba.

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.
super explanation
My Solution Is Naive, It Cost O(n^2), Is there Any Solution faster?

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

Is this part correct? 

example string: abcxycba
reverse string:  abcxycba

The substring indices are same as reversed string original indices and yet it is not a palindrome?

This post is for learner wanna practice DP.
The basic idea is, if we wanna say "aba" is palindromic, then we need to firstly confirm that "b" is palindromic, then we also need to check if "a"(the first a) = "a" (the second a).

M is a 2-d array which stores boolean values.
M[i][j] indicates if string[i.....j] is palindromic.
So base cases are:
M[i][i] is true.
M[i][i + 1] = (s[i] == s[i + 1]);
recurrence relation is :
M[i][j] = (s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1]);
For the implementation of recurrence relation, one idea is you can loop through all possible symmetry axis. For each of the axis, you expand at both RHS and LHS simultaneously. This method promises that when you are determining value in M[i][j], M[i + 1][j - 1] must have the correct value.
Final answer can be found from all M[i][j] == 1 with largest (j - i).
thank you, cat brother

I understand the solution but I don't understand why it needs any storage at all or why it needs to be a DP solution.

The condition `(s[i] == s[j] AND M[i + 1][j - 1])` requires you to memorise if `M[i+1][j-1]` is true, that's easy to understand. However, if you expand each possible axis at the same time, i.e. 1st iteration (s[i+1], s[j-1]), 2nd iteration `s[i+2], s[j-2]`, ... It is guaranteed that M[i+1][j-1] is always true and hence can be dropped, and you should break the loop when it is not true.

In summary, you don't need to memorise anything at all and you just need to check `s[i] == s[j]` while expanding in both directions at the same time, unless I have misunderstood anything? Here is an implementation of your algorithm but without storage: https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-substring/submissions/868540120/

Thank you! this is a beautiful explanation, though I\'m not sure what exactly you mean by expanding both on LHS and RHS. In my implementation it\'s enough to compute all diagonals of  the upper right triangle of the dp matrix.
super explanation

[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) So, what I did was:
Stated in my mind the Brute Force approach - create every possible substring and test each one to see if is a palindrome and find the longest.

Of course this would be ridiculously slow, so let's improve it.
I also mentally stated that a palindrome has a recursive aspect -> if single char, or two equal chars, or charX + palindrome + charX
So I created a isPalindrome recursive method that checked it delegating to itself extracting the borders.

Since a palindrome must start and end with the same char, in my traverse of the string, I started storing the position of each character Map<Character, List< Integer>>, so I would just go back to the previous found Char and check if from there to the current pointer I would have a Palindrome.

Then I stopped doing this for every possible palindrome, I then started doing only for the ones that COULD be longer than the already found longest palindrome. That accelerated a lot.

In the almost last step, I added memoization. Remember that a palindrome is like a sandwich, with the external chars being equal and the meat being another palindrome? So I stored the found palindromes using their start and and positions. So I could check if that had already being checked and if so, either return true or false directly.

The final step was to convert the recursive function to an iterative function to save some memory used by the call stack.
Maybe there are better implementations, just sharing my thought process.
[@tylerprill-rhdc](/tylerprill-rhdc) Two pointer based solution is also a really good solve here

This could be done in a single pass algorithm, but will inherently check character indices multiple times based on the nature of the problem. (basically, iterate through each, then bubble out from each index)

From the leetcode blog, one of the methods of solving this is:

A common mistake:
Some people will be tempted to come up with a quick solution, which is unfortunately flawed (however can be corrected easily):

Reverse S and become S’. Find the longest common substring between S and S’, which must also be the longest palindromic substring.
This seemed to work, let’s see some examples below.

For example,
S = “caba”, S’ = “abac”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “aba”, which is the answer.

Let’s try another example:
S = “abacdfgdcaba”, S’ = “abacdgfdcaba”.
The longest common substring between S and S’ is “abacd”. Clearly, this is not a valid palindrome.

**We could see that the longest common substring method fails when there exists a reversed copy of a non-palindromic substring in some other part of S. To rectify this, each time we find a longest common substring candidate, we check if the substring’s indices are the same as the reversed substring’s original indices. If it is, then we attempt to update the longest palindrome found so far; if not, we skip this and find the next candidate.**

Is this part correct?

reverse string:  abcxycba

The substring indices are same as reversed string original indices and yet it is not a palindrome?

Algorithm A: "Expand Around Center" (approach 4 described in the solution).
O(n) best case (string contains no palindromes).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of one repeated character).

Algorithm B: modified version of algorithm A that looks ahead to the end of a substring consisting of one repeated character, and expands around the whole substring, avoiding the effort of expanding around each position within the substring.
O(n) best case (string consists of one repeated character).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of two alternating characters, like "ababab".)

Algorithm C: Manacher's.
O(n) best and worst case.

Implemented in C++, algorithm A runs in 44 ms, while algorithms B and C both run in 4 ms. Apparently, algorithm A is encountering its worst case but algorithm B is not.

Sure enough, when tested on "ab" repeated 5,000 times, algorithms A and B both run in ~100 ms and algorithm C runs in ~0 ms.

So it appears that in the test cases, there's a long string of one repeated character but no similarly long string of two alternating characters.

Just something I find interesting.

Hi, 

Many Manacher’s Algorithm implementation threads over the internet, but they always handle the even string case as:

"We just add $ to the string before and after, so baba would be $b$a$b$a$ and now we can have this case working too..."

But it's kind of defeating the purpose of having a O(n) time complexity, because you are doing another O(n) just to add the $, and then another O(n) to remove the $ for the even case. 

Maybe there is another Manchester's implementation that doesn't require that tricky "add $" in order to work.

For my solution I had two pases, one for the even and one for the odd, but I feel dumb when I see solutions from other people.. still 14 ms.

For folks getting a TLE. There are certain optimisations that work which would not work for smaller inputs.\nIf you think about it logically the constant in dictionary look up is substantially higher that that of a list look up. However, we need to create a list and initialise it. This is where the constant in dictionary look up is traded off by default dict.\n
Could someone help me understand how the time complexity is o(n^3) for the brute force?
There are O(N^2) sub-strings. Checking whether a string is a palindrome is O(N). So O(N^3)

O(n3) runtime, O(1) space – Brute force:
The obvious brute force solution is to pick all possible starting and ending positions for a substring, and verify if it is a palindrome. There are a total of such substrings (excluding the trivial solution where a character itself is a palindrome).
Since verifying each substring takes O(n) time, the run time complexity is O(n3).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132859.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(n) space – Dynamic programming:
To improve over the brute force solution from a DP approach, first think how we can avoid unnecessary re-computation in validating palindromes. Consider the case “ababa”.
If we already knew that “bab” is a palindrome, it is obvious that “ababa” must be a palindrome since the two left and right end letters are the same.
Stated more formally below:
	Define P[ i, j ] ← true if the substring Si … Sj is a palindrome, otherwise false.
	Therefore,
	P[ i, j ] ← ( P[ i+1, j-1 ] and Si = Sj )
	The base cases are:
	P[ i, i ] ← true
	P[ i, i+1 ] ← ( Si = Si+1 )
This yields a straight forward DP solution, which we first initialize the one and two letters palindromes, and work our way up finding all three letters palindromes, and so on…
This gives us a runtime complexity of O(n2) and uses O(n2) space to store the table.
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132896.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(1) space – Simpler solution:
In fact, we could solve it in O(n2) time using only constant space.
We observe that a palindrome mirrors around its center. Therefore, a palindrome can be expanded from its center, and there are only 2n – 1 such centers.
You might be asking why there are 2n – 1 but not n centers? The reason is the center of a palindrome can be in between two letters. Such palindromes have even number of letters (such as “abba”) and its center are between the two ‘b’s.
Since expanding a palindrome around its center could take O(n) time, the overall complexity is O(n2).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132950.png)

O(n) runtime, O(n) space – Manacher’s algorithm:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132981.png)

![alt text]![0_1499137449406_8cb1c4ff-b5a3-46f1-9aeb-eed2e7012534-image.png](/assets/uploads/files/1499137454573-8cb1c4ff-b5a3-46f1-9aeb-eed2e7012534-image-resized.png) \nHow should i deal with this problem?

Algorithm A: "Expand Around Center" (approach 4 described in the solution).
O(n) best case (string contains no palindromes).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of one repeated character).

Algorithm B: modified version of algorithm A that looks ahead to the end of a substring consisting of one repeated character, and expands around the whole substring, avoiding the effort of expanding around each position within the substring.
O(n) best case (string consists of one repeated character).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of two alternating characters, like "ababab".)

Algorithm C: Manacher's.
O(n) best and worst case.

Implemented in C++, algorithm A runs in 44 ms, while algorithms B and C both run in 4 ms. Apparently, algorithm A is encountering its worst case but algorithm B is not.

Sure enough, when tested on "ab" repeated 5,000 times, algorithms A and B both run in ~100 ms and algorithm C runs in ~0 ms.

So it appears that in the test cases, there's a long string of one repeated character but no similarly long string of two alternating characters.

Just something I find interesting.

I would like to report a bug here that, my solution runs successfully on all except the last testcase. When it shows that test case failed, I looked and found that the test case was empty, I mean such a minor bug in test case checking caused bad effect on my accuracy. Please remove the last test case. :(
agreed. it also directly contradicts the two constraints given in the problem. Even if you were to write a testcase accounting for an empty string it still does not work for some reason.
"Time Limit Exceeded" On Passing solution...\n\nHonestly sounds like an excuse to reduce server load.

Key to this task is avoiding string operations in your solution.  It can save you enormous time and avoids the TLE error.  Going one by one or using two loops stripping on char off the front or back doesn\'t matter.  Reduce it all to int operations and it simplifies the task immensely.  That\'s my two cents and I\'m sticking with it. Cheers!

Hi, 

Many Manacher’s Algorithm implementation threads over the internet, but they always handle the even string case as:

"We just add $ to the string before and after, so baba would be $b$a$b$a$ and now we can have this case working too..."

But it's kind of defeating the purpose of having a O(n) time complexity, because you are doing another O(n) just to add the $, and then another O(n) to remove the $ for the even case. 

Maybe there is another Manchester's implementation that doesn't require that tricky "add $" in order to work.

For my solution I had two pases, one for the even and one for the odd, but I feel dumb when I see solutions from other people.. still 14 ms.

For folks getting a TLE. There are certain optimisations that work which would not work for smaller inputs.\nIf you think about it logically the constant in dictionary look up is substantially higher that that of a list look up. However, we need to create a list and initialise it. This is where the constant in dictionary look up is traded off by default dict.\n
Could someone help me understand how the time complexity is o(n^3) for the brute force?
There are O(N^2) sub-strings. Checking whether a string is a palindrome is O(N). So O(N^3)

O(n3) runtime, O(1) space – Brute force:
The obvious brute force solution is to pick all possible starting and ending positions for a substring, and verify if it is a palindrome. There are a total of such substrings (excluding the trivial solution where a character itself is a palindrome).
Since verifying each substring takes O(n) time, the run time complexity is O(n3).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132859.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(n) space – Dynamic programming:
To improve over the brute force solution from a DP approach, first think how we can avoid unnecessary re-computation in validating palindromes. Consider the case “ababa”.
If we already knew that “bab” is a palindrome, it is obvious that “ababa” must be a palindrome since the two left and right end letters are the same.
Stated more formally below:
	Define P[ i, j ] ← true if the substring Si … Sj is a palindrome, otherwise false.
	Therefore,
	P[ i, j ] ← ( P[ i+1, j-1 ] and Si = Sj )
	The base cases are:
	P[ i, i ] ← true
	P[ i, i+1 ] ← ( Si = Si+1 )
This yields a straight forward DP solution, which we first initialize the one and two letters palindromes, and work our way up finding all three letters palindromes, and so on…
This gives us a runtime complexity of O(n2) and uses O(n2) space to store the table.
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132896.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(1) space – Simpler solution:
In fact, we could solve it in O(n2) time using only constant space.
We observe that a palindrome mirrors around its center. Therefore, a palindrome can be expanded from its center, and there are only 2n – 1 such centers.
You might be asking why there are 2n – 1 but not n centers? The reason is the center of a palindrome can be in between two letters. Such palindromes have even number of letters (such as “abba”) and its center are between the two ‘b’s.
Since expanding a palindrome around its center could take O(n) time, the overall complexity is O(n2).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132950.png)

O(n) runtime, O(n) space – Manacher’s algorithm:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132981.png)

Algorithm A: "Expand Around Center" (approach 4 described in the solution).

O(n^2) worst case (string consists of one repeated character).

Algorithm B: modified version of algorithm A that looks ahead to the end of a substring consisting of one repeated character, and expands around the whole substring, avoiding the effort of expanding around each position within the substring.
O(n) best case (string consists of one repeated character).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of two alternating characters, like "ababab".)

Algorithm C: Manacher's.
O(n) best and worst case.

Implemented in C++, algorithm A runs in 44 ms, while algorithms B and C both run in 4 ms. Apparently, algorithm A is encountering its worst case but algorithm B is not.

Sure enough, when tested on "ab" repeated 5,000 times, algorithms A and B both run in ~100 ms and algorithm C runs in ~0 ms.

So it appears that in the test cases, there's a long string of one repeated character but no similarly long string of two alternating characters.

Just something I find interesting.

Since expanding a palindrome around its center could take O(n) time, the overall complexity is O(n2).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132950.png)

O(n) runtime, O(n) space – Manacher’s algorithm:
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132981.png)

![alt text]![0_1499137449406_8cb1c4ff-b5a3-46f1-9aeb-eed2e7012534-image.png](/assets/uploads/files/1499137454573-8cb1c4ff-b5a3-46f1-9aeb-eed2e7012534-image-resized.png) \nHow should i deal with this problem?

Algorithm A: "Expand Around Center" (approach 4 described in the solution).
O(n) best case (string contains no palindromes).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of one repeated character).

Algorithm B: modified version of algorithm A that looks ahead to the end of a substring consisting of one repeated character, and expands around the whole substring, avoiding the effort of expanding around each position within the substring.
O(n) best case (string consists of one repeated character).
O(n^2) worst case (string consists of two alternating characters, like "ababab".)

Algorithm C: Manacher's.
O(n) best and worst case.

Implemented in C++, algorithm A runs in 44 ms, while algorithms B and C both run in 4 ms. Apparently, algorithm A is encountering its worst case but algorithm B is not.

Sure enough, when tested on "ab" repeated 5,000 times, algorithms A and B both run in ~100 ms and algorithm C runs in ~0 ms.

So it appears that in the test cases, there's a long string of one repeated character but no similarly long string of two alternating characters.

Just something I find interesting.

Could someone help me understand how the time complexity is o(n^3) for the brute force?
There are O(N^2) sub-strings. Checking whether a string is a palindrome is O(N). So O(N^3)

O(n3) runtime, O(1) space – Brute force:
The obvious brute force solution is to pick all possible starting and ending positions for a substring, and verify if it is a palindrome. There are a total of such substrings (excluding the trivial solution where a character itself is a palindrome).
Since verifying each substring takes O(n) time, the run time complexity is O(n3).
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132859.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(n) space – Dynamic programming:
To improve over the brute force solution from a DP approach, first think how we can avoid unnecessary re-computation in validating palindromes. Consider the case “ababa”.
If we already knew that “bab” is a palindrome, it is obvious that “ababa” must be a palindrome since the two left and right end letters are the same.
Stated more formally below:
	Define P[ i, j ] ← true if the substring Si … Sj is a palindrome, otherwise false.
	Therefore,
	P[ i, j ] ← ( P[ i+1, j-1 ] and Si = Sj )
	The base cases are:
	P[ i, i ] ← true
	P[ i, i+1 ] ← ( Si = Si+1 )
This yields a straight forward DP solution, which we first initialize the one and two letters palindromes, and work our way up finding all three letters palindromes, and so on…
This gives us a runtime complexity of O(n2) and uses O(n2) space to store the table.
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/infoie/image_1576132896.png)

O(n2) runtime, O(1) space – Simpler solution:
In fact, we could solve it in O(n2) time using only constant space.
We observe that a palindrome mirrors around its center. Therefore, a palindrome can be expanded from its center, and there are only 2n – 1 such centers.
You might be asking why there are 2n – 1 but not n centers? The reason is the center of a palindrome can be in between two letters. Such palindromes have even number of letters (such as “abba”) and its center are between the two ‘b’s.

## Intuition 
- The problem is to find the longest palndromic substring within a given string.
- A palindrome reads the same backward as forward.
- We can use a brute-force approach to check all possible substrings and find the longest one that is also a palindrome.

## Approach
- Define an ```isPalindrome``` method to check if substring is a palindrome. This method compares characters from the start and end of the substring, moving toward the center.
- In the ```longestPalindrome``` method:
- Initialize variables ```maxLength``` to store the length of the longest palindrome found so far and start to store the starting index of the longest palindrome.
- Iterate through all possible pairs of indexes (i, j) to consider all substrings.
- For each substring (i, j) check if it's a palindrome using the ```isPalindrome``` method.
- If it's a palindrome and longer than the current maximum, update ```maxLength``` and start.

Variable Sliding window is used when we have to find a subarry or substring with a condition. Find max subarray with distinct chars.\nNow why is this a DP and not sliding window as we have to find a min substring with palindrome.
Refer below for non-DP solution and well-commented code in C++, Java and Python:\nhttps://www.techiedelight.com/longest-palindromic-substring-non-dp-space-optimized-solution/

Using dynamic programming algorithm, the memorization table dp[i,j] shows the maximum palindromic substring lengith is 3.  Then the answer is "aba". However, leetcode rejects the this answer.  Please help me understand why the accepted answer is "a" instead of "aba". \n

Input:
"abcdasdfghjkldcba"
Output:
"abcd"
Expected:
"a"

obviously s[0:4] = 'abcd' while s[-5:-1]='dcba' so the answer should be 'abcd'
the problem is, you don\'t know what a palindrome is..."abcd" != "dcba", if that were the case you would return the whole string and then there would be no point to the exercise

I got Wrong Answer on test:
Input:"abcda"
Output:""
Expected:"a"
Is "a" a palindrom?
stop posting solutions
A substring from index i to j can be palindrome only if the substring from index i+1 to j-1 is palindrome and characters at index i and j are equal \ndp[i][j]=1 only if dp[i+1][j-1]==1 and s[i]==s[j]

A substring from index i to j can be palindrome only if the substring from index i+1 to j-1 is palindrome and characters at index i and j are equal \ndp[i][j]=1 only if dp[i+1][j-1]==1 and s[i]==s[j]

Variable Sliding window is used when we have to find a subarry or substring with a condition. Find max subarray with distinct chars.\nNow why is this a DP and not sliding window as we have to find a min substring with palindrome.
Refer below for non-DP solution and well-commented code in C++, Java and Python:\nhttps://www.techiedelight.com/longest-palindromic-substring-non-dp-space-optimized-solution/

Using dynamic programming algorithm, the memorization table dp[i,j] shows the maximum palindromic substring lengith is 3.  Then the answer is "aba". However, leetcode rejects the this answer.  Please help me understand why the accepted answer is "a" instead of "aba". \n

Input:
"abcdasdfghjkldcba"
Output:
"abcd"
Expected:
"a"

obviously s[0:4] = 'abcd' while s[-5:-1]='dcba' so the answer should be 'abcd'
the problem is, you don\'t know what a palindrome is..."abcd" != "dcba", if that were the case you would return the whole string and then there would be no point to the exercise

To solve this you only need to mind two things. 
one, Palindrome can't have with more than one even number of character duplicate.
two, all single character should be ignore you only need to add one single character if the result total number is odd. example the total none single character of string is 6 and you can place single character on the middle of the string so it become 7.

"aacabdkacaa"

"aacakacaa" is a subsequence of input string not it's substring, as the question is to find substring that's where you are getting wrong.
For example : let string = "abcdef"
it's substrings: 'a' 'ab' 'abc' 'cde' 'abcde' ...
it's subsequences : 'a' 'ab' 'ac' 'acf' 'abe' ...

I solved this problem for the first submit by brute-force and beat >60%.
Just try to think in every position you will a Palindromic, move left and right to get the Longest match.
We only have two case for each: left=i-1, r=i+1 and left=i, right=i+1;
Total is O(n^2) complexity, O(1) space.

I have the below approach in mind:

when you get the longest length, 
1. we need to get the palindrome with that length.
2. We need to reduce length to be checked by -1
3. shift left the window by 1 by fixing the end and moving only left index by 1 until there is only value 1 difference between start and end while end > start
4. shift left the window by 1 by fixing the end and moving only right index by 1 until there is only value 1 difference between start and end while end > start
5. the above to loop around until we have the i reaching end of the string.

There seems to be an extra curly brace at the end of your code, which may be causing a syntax error. However, assuming that this is a typographical error, the most likely reason why your code is exceeding the limit is because the time complexity of the algorithm is high.

The code is using a recursive function to check all possible substrings in the input string s, and then checking if they are palindromes or not using the check() function. This approach has an exponential time complexity of O(2^n), where n is the length of the input string s.

This means that as the length of the input string grows, the number of recursive calls made by the algorithm also grows exponentially, leading to a potential stack overflow or timeout.

To optimize the algorithm, you can use dynamic programming or expand around the center approach to reduce the time complexity to O(n2).

Dynamic Programming Approach:

- Define a boolean table of size n x n, where n is the length of the input string.
- Initialize all cells in the table to false.
- Set all cells (i, i) to true, since a single character is always a palindrome.
- For all pairs of indices i, j where i < j, set table[i][j] to true if s[i] == s[j] and table[i+1][j-1] is also true. - This means that a substring from i to j is a palindrome if its first and last characters are equal, and its - inner substring is also a palindrome.
- Keep track of the longest palindrome found so far and its starting and ending indices.

class Solution(object):
    def longestPalindrome(self, s):
        left = 0
        dp=""
        
        for i in range(len(s)):
            left = i +1
            cur = ""
            while left<=len(s):
                # print(s[i:left])
                cur = s[i:left] if s[i:left]==s[i:left][::-1] else cur 
                left+=1 
            dp = max(dp,cur,key=len)
      
        return dp 
```

It utilizes the idea that if a palindrome has its center at the current position and its right boundary has reached position j, then the palindrome with its center at the current position will have the same length as the palindrome with its center at the symmetrical position of j with respect to the current position, as long as j is within the boundary of the palindrome with center at the current position.

The C++ code provided implements Manacher's algorithm to find the longest palindromic substring in a given input string.

The code starts by defining a function named "longestPalindrome" which takes a string as its input and returns a string as its output.

The first step in the function is to preprocess the input string by inserting special characters between each character and also at the beginning and end of the string. This is done by creating a new string "temp" and iterating through each character in the input string, adding it to "temp" and also adding the special character "#" after it. This modified string is then stored in "s".

Next, the code defines two arrays "p" and "id" of size n+1, where n is the length of the modified string. The array "p" is used to hold the length of the palindrome centered at each character in the modified string and the array "id" is used to keep track of the center and right boundary of the current palindrome.

The code then initializes two variables "mx" and "id" to 0 and assigns the value 0 to all elements of the "p" array.

The algorithm then starts iterating through each character in the modified string using a for loop, for each i in s.

The first thing the code does inside the for loop is to check if the current character is within the right boundary of the previous palindrome. If so, it uses the "mirroring" technique to calculate the length of the palindrome centered at the current character. It sets the value of "p[i]" to the minimum of "p[(id*2-i)" and "mx-i".

Otherwise, the code falls back to the "expanding around the center" technique and starts checking the characters on both sides of the current character to find the length of the palindrome centered at the current character.

The code then updates the "mx" and "id" variables if the current palindrome exceeds the right boundary of the previous palindrome.

Finally, the code finds the center and length of the longest palindrome by iterating through the "p" array and returning the substring of the original input string using the center and length information.

class Solution:
    def longestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        n, l, i, temp, s1 = [len(s), 1, 0, 0, s[::-1]] 
        if s1==s: return s 
        while i+l <= n-1:
            for j in range(l,n-i+1):
                if s1[i:i+j] ==s[n-j-i:n-i]: l=j; temp=i
                if s1[i:i+j] not in s: break
            if i<=n-l-1:    i+=1; continue 
            else: break 
        if temp==0 and l==1: return s[0]
        return s[n-l-temp:n-temp]  
```

[@zohairhadi2000](/zohairhadi2000) This code will get in trouble even for simple testcase:
s= "bbbbbbbb"
Why?

Because you didnt define a boundary condition for string that you check on:
```
if s[i-1] == s[i+1]:
            count = 2
            while (s[i-count] == s[i+count]):
                count += 1
            count -= 1
            temp_longest = s[i-count: i+count + 1]
```
What if? s[i-count], i-count<0?, i+count>len(s)-1. It returns a 
_IndexError: string index out of range_ right

So first, check your condition, then run dry test (change some simple case by yourself). 

You can use a slide windows to check, and only check to len(s)-l-1, l=max last found palindromic substring.

```
class Solution:
    def longestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
        n, l, i, temp, s1 = [len(s), 1, 0, 0, s[::-1]] 
        if s1==s: return s 
        while i+l <= n-1:
            for j in range(l,n-i+1):
                if s1[i:i+j] ==s[n-j-i:n-i]: l=j; temp=i
                if s1[i:i+j] not in s: break
            if i<=n-l-1:    i+=1; continue 
            else: break 
        if temp==0 and l==1: return s[0]
        return s[n-l-temp:n-temp]  
```

A faster solution with time complexity of O(n) is the Manacher algorithm. It utilizes the idea that if a palindrome has its center at the current position and its right boundary has reached position j, then the palindrome with its center at the current position will have the same length as the palindrome with its center at the symmetrical position of j with respect to the current position, as long as j is within the boundary of the palindrome with center at the current position.

The C++ code provided implements Manacher's algorithm to find the longest palindromic substring in a given input string.

The code starts by defining a function named "longestPalindrome" which takes a string as its input and returns a string as its output.

The first step in the function is to preprocess the input string by inserting special characters between each character and also at the beginning and end of the string. This is done by creating a new string "temp" and iterating through each character in the input string, adding it to "temp" and also adding the special character "#" after it. This modified string is then stored in "s".

Next, the code defines two arrays "p" and "id" of size n+1, where n is the length of the modified string. The array "p" is used to hold the length of the palindrome centered at each character in the modified string and the array "id" is used to keep track of the center and right boundary of the current palindrome.

The code then initializes two variables "mx" and "id" to 0 and assigns the value 0 to all elements of the "p" array.

The algorithm then starts iterating through each character in the modified string using a for loop, for each i in s.

The first thing the code does inside the for loop is to check if the current character is within the right boundary of the previous palindrome. If so, it uses the "mirroring" technique to calculate the length of the palindrome centered at the current character. It sets the value of "p[i]" to the minimum of "p[(id*2-i)" and "mx-i".

Otherwise, the code falls back to the "expanding around the center" technique and starts checking the characters on both sides of the current character to find the length of the palindrome centered at the current character.

The code then updates the "mx" and "id" variables if the current palindrome exceeds the right boundary of the previous palindrome.

Finally, the code finds the center and length of the longest palindrome by iterating through the "p" array and returning the substring of the original input string using the center and length information.

It's important to note that the above code is just an example and this specific implementation may be different from other ones, but the overall idea and algorithm remains the same.

Hi I haven't studied Dynamic Programming till now but learned a littlebit about memoization. I tried to solve this problem with recursion + adding memoization .

Code gives exactly what we want but off-course Time-Limit issues.

Just want to ask where does this approach fail?

`
dp = {}
def longestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
if self.dp.get(s) != None:
    return self.dp[s]

#TRACKERS
lenStr = len(s)

#BASE
if lenStr == 1:
    self.dp[s] = s
    return s

if s == s[::-1]:
    self.dp[s] = s
    return s
else:
    lp_inleft = self.longestPalindrome(s[1:])
    lp_inright = self.longestPalindrome(s[:lenStr-1])
    ans = max(lp_inleft,lp_inright,key=len)
    self.dp[s] = ans
    return ans
        `

"badab" or "abdba" is both palindromic (the same read forwards and backwards) and a substring. And its obviously longer than "bab". For that matter, why isn't "baab" accepted?

My definitions:
A palindrome is a string that is the same if it's read forward and backward.
A substring is a string that rearranges or omits characters of a string.

`
dp = {}
def longestPalindrome(self, s: str) -> str:
if self.dp.get(s) != None:
    return self.dp[s]

#TRACKERS
lenStr = len(s)

#BASE
if lenStr == 1:
    self.dp[s] = s
    return s

if s == s[::-1]:
    self.dp[s] = s
    return s
else:
    lp_inleft = self.longestPalindrome(s[1:])
    lp_inright = self.longestPalindrome(s[:lenStr-1])
    ans = max(lp_inleft,lp_inright,key=len)
    self.dp[s] = ans
    return ans
        `
